TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE in GPE , GPE . She was a citizen of the former GPE and continued to hold its citizenship until DATE ; thereafter she became a stateless person . The applicant lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied to the passport department at the “ GPE ” police station in GPE for residence registration . She produced her GPE passport , a consent form signed by the flat owner and certified by the housing maintenance authority , an application form for residence registration , a document showing payment of housing maintenance charges and an extract from the ORG list .

CARDINAL . NORP The Director of the passport department refused to process the application for residence registration . He told the applicant that she could not be registered because she was not a relative of the flat owner .

CARDINAL . The applicant insisted on a written refusal . She was given a printed form on which a checkmark was placed next to the statement “ failed to provide a complete set of documents ” . It was not specified which documents were missing .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant challenged the refusal before ORG of GPE . She submitted that there had been no legal basis for a restriction on her right to obtain residence registration in the flat , expressly provided to her for that purpose by its owner , and that the registration authorities had no discretion in granting residence registration once the appropriate documents had been produced , as had been the case .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Director of the passport department filed his observations on the applicant ’s claim . He contended that the applicant did not have NORP citizenship and that she had originally come from GPE . NORP citizens were required to have an appropriate visa to enter GPE , which the applicant could not produce , and , in any event , the registration of foreign citizens was a matter for ORG local visa departments .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE ruled on the applicant ’s claim . A representative of the flat owner stated before the court that the applicant had been living in the flat since DATE and that the owner had no objections to her registration . The court dismissed the applicant ’s claim , giving CARDINAL reasons for its decision .

CARDINAL . Firstly , referring to the provisions of ORG regulating the joining of family members and other persons to existing municipal - tenancy agreements and emphasising the absence of a family relationship between the applicant and the flat owner , the court ruled that the matter should be examined not as a challenge to the ORG official ’s refusal to grant registration , but rather as a civil action for determination of the applicant ’s right to move into the flat .

CARDINAL . Secondly , the court held that the applicant had failed to prove her LANGUAGE citizenship or to confirm her intention of obtaining it and pointed out that “ a treaty ” between GPE and GPE provided for visa - based exchanges .
CARDINAL . The judgment concluded as follows :

“ Given that the applicant failed to produce information confirming her right to move into the flat in question , information on [ her ] citizenship and the lawfulness of [ her ] entry into GPE , the ORG accordingly dismisses her claim . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE confirmed certain amendments to the hearing record , as submitted by the applicant ’s representative . In particular , the record was to reflect the applicant ’s statements about the non - applicability of municipal - tenancy provisions to her situation , given that the flat had been in private ownership , and about the flat owner ’s consent to her residence .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s representative filed a statement of appeal . He submitted , in particular , that ORG had incorrectly referred to the applicant ’s NORP citizenship and to a visa requirement for her entry into GPE , since the applicant had never held NORP citizenship and , in any event , the residence regulations applied uniformly to all persons lawfully residing within GPE , irrespective of their citizenship . He indicated that ORG had failed to advance any justification for the restriction on the applicant ’s right to choose her residence . He also contended that ORG reliance on tenancy provisions had been invalid because the flat owner had had clear title to the flat and there could be no dispute as to the applicant ’s right to move in , since she had the flat owner ’s explicit consent .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment . It reiterated ORG findings that the applicant ’s claim had to be dismissed because she had failed to prove her NORP citizenship or an intention to obtain it and because she had failed to provide any documents confirming her right to move into the flat in question . ORG did not address the arguments advanced by the applicant ’s representative in the grounds of appeal .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides for the equality of all before the law and the courts of law , and equality of rights and liberties .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides that everyone lawfully within the territory of the NORP Federation shall have the right to move freely and choose his or her place of stay or residence .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that foreign citizens and stateless persons shall have the same rights and obligations in GPE as NORP citizens unless otherwise provided in a federal law or an international treaty to which GPE is a party .

CARDINAL . At the material time the issues related to NORP citizenship were governed by the Citizenship of GPE ( Law no . CARDINAL-I of DATE , as amended on DATE ) , which provided that all citizens of the former GPE who were permanently resident in GPE on DATE ( the date of entry into force of the Act ) automatically obtained NORP citizenship unless they expressed their wish to the contrary before DATE . The basis for establishing whether a person was permanently resident within GPE was the propiska stamp ( internal residence registration ) in his or her GPE passport . Section CARDINAL(g ) of the law provided for a simplified procedure ( “ by way of registration ” ) for obtaining NORP citizenship for citizens of the former GPE who arrived in GPE after DATE and expressed their wish to become NORP citizens before DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP Under the powers vested in him by law , on DATE the President of GPE adopted the Regulations on the procedure for consideration of issues of citizenship of GPE ( Decree no . CARDINAL – “ the DATE LAW ) . Section II(CARDINAL ) stated that the notion of “ a citizen of the former GPE ” applied only to those individuals who did not obtain the citizenship of one of the newly independent GPE which had previously been members of the GPE . The same section stipulated that after DATE all citizens of the former GPE who had not obtained NORP or other citizenship would be considered to be stateless persons .

CARDINAL . Until DATE the status of foreign citizens and stateless persons in GPE was regulated by LAW on the legal status of foreign citizens in the GPE ( no . CARDINAL-X of DATE , as amended on DATE “ the DATE GPE Law ” ) . By virtue of section DATE , its provisions were likewise applicable to stateless persons .

CARDINAL . In implementation of the DATE GPE Law , on DATE ORG no . CARDINAL , whereby it approved the Rules on the stay of foreign citizens in the GPE ( “ the DATE Rules ” ) . Those rules also applied to stateless persons and described the procedures for entering and leaving GPE , obtaining documents for temporary residence and permanent residence , etc .

CARDINAL . On DATE CARDINAL member GPE of ORG ( ORG ) , including GPE , signed in GPE an Agreement on visa - free movement of citizens of member ORG throughout their territory ( “ the Bishkek Agreement ” ) . GPE acceded to LAW on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG denounced GPE as of DATE . In the absence of a bilateral agreement on visa - free movement between GPE and GPE , NORP citizens were required to apply for a NORP entry visa from DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE GPE adopted a PERSON on the right of NORP citizens to liberty of movement and freedom to choose their place of temporary and permanent residence within GPE ( Law no . MONEY – “ the DATE LAW ) . LAW guaranteed the right of NORP citizens to liberty of movement and freedom to choose their place of residence , and extended the law ’s application to non - NORP citizens lawfully residing in NORP territory . Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL required a person to apply for residence registration at a new address within DATE of moving . Section CARDINAL contained an exhaustive list of territories where this right could be restricted ( such as military settlements , environmental disaster zones , etc . )

CARDINAL . NORP In order to implement the DATE Law , on DATE the NORP government approved the Regulations for registration of temporary and permanent residence of NORP citizens ( no . CARDINAL ) . By Government Resolution no . CARDINAL of DATE , the application of these Regulations was extended to former GPE citizens arriving from ORG and GPE . LAW imposed a general duty to seek residence registration at any address where a person intended to stay for DATE . The person was required to file an application for registration within DATE of the move and to submit an identity document , an application form and a document showing the legal basis for residence at the indicated address ( such as a rent contract or the consent of the flat owner ) . LAW , as worded at the material time , provided that the registration could be refused if the applicant had not submitted written consent or had produced manifestly false documents ; the list of grounds for refusal was exhaustive .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE struck down certain provisions of the Regulations as incompatible with LAW . It ruled , in particular , that

“ ... the registration authorities are entitled only to certify the freely expressed will of a citizen in his or her choice of ... residence . For this reason , the registration system may not be permission - based and it shall not entail a restriction on the citizen ’s constitutional right to choose his or her place of ... residence . Thus , the registration system in the sense which is compatible with LAW is merely a means ... of counting people within GPE , ... is notice - based and reflects the fact of a citizen ’s stay at a place of his or her temporary or permanent residence . ”

The Constitutional Court emphasised that , upon presentation of an identity document and a document confirming the person ’s right to reside at the chosen address , the registration authority should have no discretion and should register the person concerned at the address indicated . The requirement to submit any additional document might lead to “ paralysis of a citizen ’s rights ” . On that ground ORG ruled that the registration authorities were not entitled to verify the authenticity of the submitted documents or their compliance with NORP laws and , accordingly , any such grounds for refusal were unconstitutional .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE authorities passed a PERSON on the conditions of residence in GPE for foreign citizens who have the right to enter GPE without a visa ( Law no . CARDINAL ) . The PERSON applied to foreign citizens from the ORG and to stateless persons . It required non - NORP citizens to apply for residence registration within DATE of their arrival ( if staying for DATE ) . Section CARDINAL of the PERSON provided that a non - NORP citizen residing in GPE for DATE without the appropriate residence registration was liable to a fine of CARDINAL Russian roubles ( RUR ) ( approximately CARDINAL euros ( ORG ) in DATE ) or , in the event of a repeated offence , up to RUR CARDINAL,CARDINAL ( EUR CARDINAL ) . The same penalty could be imposed on a flat owner who permitted a non - NORP citizen to live in his or her LOC without residence registration .
